Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dissolved pyrogenic organic matter dynamics in the environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pyrogenic organic matter, or black carbon (BC), is derived from the incomplete combustion of biomass and fossil fuels. It is now recognized that this type of organic matter has a great impact on soil chemistry, transport of pollutants, climate and global carbon cycling. Further, its impacts will likely grow due to increased climate change-related wildfires and intentional addition of BC (as biochar) to soils to enhance soil fertility and carbon sequestration. However, while knowledge of the properties of natural and anthropogenic particulate BC has increased in recent years, there has been relatively little study of the properties and cycling of the organic matter that can leach from BC; pyrogenic dissolved organic matter (py-DOM). Although release of py-DOM into the environment may have unrecognized carbon cycling and environmental impacts, py-DOM has been quantified in only a few systems using methods that have not been comprehensively evaluated. This research will examine the fundamental chemical properties and mechanisms associated with py-DOM production and fate and the chemical markers used to quantify it. In addition, in order to broaden general awareness of the importance of fire on climate and the carbon cycle, the investigators will develop an interactive exhibit at a local hands-on science museum that will include touch screen graphics, narrated videos by each of the principal investigators illustrating the scientific process and the research results.

To establish the chemical properties and mechanisms associated with py-DOM production and fate and the chemical markers used to quantify it, the project will: 1) produce py-DOM from a logical series of BC solids, both freshly produced and "aged" via microbial and photic treatments, 2) chemically characterize these BC parent solids and their aqueous dissolved products using FTIR, Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry (FTICR-MS) and 1- and 2-dimensional NMR, 3) examine py-DOM loss and transformation after microbial and photodegradation treatments, and 4) quantify the yields of putative pyrogenic molecular markers; levoglucosan, benzenepolycarboxylic acids (BPCA) and oxygenated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (O-PAH), from fresh and "aged" BC solids and leachates. Using the same methods and experiments, the leachates and leachate alteration products of potentially interfering non-pyrogenic terrestrial organic materials, some of which the investigators have recently shown to contain "BC-like" compounds will also be examined. This work will test whether py-DOM chemistry can be linked to its parent BC type and "aging" processes, the extent to which py-DOM and its molecular markers undergo major losses and chemical transformation through microbial and photo-oxidation, and whether currently used molecular markers for py-DOM accurately represent actual pyrogenic OM contributions to environmental samples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Char materials are produced from wildfires in the environment and, more recently, commercially as biochars for agricultural and pollution remediation purposes. These char materials have previously been thought to be unreactive and efficiently buried in soils thereby sequestering carbon from the atmosphere into soils. The sequestration of carbon can counteract, to an extent, reduce the amount of greenhouse gases emitted to the atmosphere. Recent research has found that a portion of these charred substances is not so stable and can leach after rain events into rivers, lakes, swamps, estuaries, and the global ocean. This means that less of these char materials is sequestered than previously thought. During their cycling in the environment, these substances can be degraded by irradiation from the sun, provide a food source to bacteria or fungi and therefore contribute to soil and sediment health, or alternatively be poisonous to microorganisms. Because commercial biochar use and wildfires are both projected to increase in coming years, it is vital that we understand how these leached materials behave in the environment and what factors (vegetation type, fire temperature, degradation by light and microbes) influence that behavior. This project performed experiments simulating the three main aspects of the cycling of pyrogenic substances: 1) Char formation during fire and subsequent leaching by rain; 2) Photo-transformation by solar irradiation in shallow aquatic environments (for example, rivers, lakes, ocean, etc.), and 3) Char?s ability to support microbes and fungi in dark environments (soils and sediments). A variety of advanced chemical characterization techniques were used to assess the amounts and types of compounds that are produced and consumed by these processes and provide insight into the role of pyrogenic (char) substances in the carbon cycle.

We find that a significant amount of pyrogenic substances (and carbon) are leached to aquatic environments. The amounts and types of carbon compounds that can be leached into aquatic environments are quite variable and depend on the vegetation (oak versus grass, in this study) that is burned as well as the temperature at which it is burned. Many of the leached compounds have characteristics of stable and/or toxic compounds, while many more compounds appear similar to that found in natural organic matter and likely provide a carbon source to aquatic organisms. We also find that light readily photo-transforms many of the leached char compounds yielding carbon dioxide and various organic matter byproducts, many of which can be further used as a carbon source for aquatic microorganisms. In dark environments (such as soils, sediments, and deeper parts of water bodies), bacteria and fungi do not efficiently feed on these molecules, which explains the previously observed unreactivity (recalcitrance) and accumulation in soils and sediments. These outcomes are important for understanding the global cycling of chars given their newly appreciated abundance in our environments. For example, a fire in a grassland can be expected to release more carbon and very different compounds to rivers compared to a fire in an oak forest at the same temperature. As another example, a fire in an oak forest at 650 degrees Celsius releases less carbon into aquatic environments than one that burns at 250 degrees Celsius. However, the fire at 650 degrees Celsius releases carbon compounds that have characteristics that make them more susceptible to transformation by light ? or to sequestration, and potentially toxic effects, in dark environments. The insights derived from this work could not have been discovered without the use of advanced mass spectrometry and spectroscopy technologies and give us a better understanding of the impacts of fire-produced materials in the environment.
